results.title: The Blob (1988)
results.creator_credit: Chuck Russell, Elliott Kastner, Jack H. Harris and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: Terror has no shape is the tagline for “The Blob” - the same could be said for this re-make of the 1950s B-grade horror classic. After the successful re-make of “The Fly” by horror maestro David Cronenberg, many sought to ape this accomplishment with a slew of films drawing on the 50s horror genre. Director Chuck Russell utilises the familiar milieu of small-town America as his setting - when a huge meteorite hurtles toward earth and crash lands, a large amorphous mass starts to reproduce itself, becoming a menacing and murderous force. Initially the local townsfolk are disbelieving, but soon many are grusomely mutilated in an endless night of terror. A young, staunchly anti-authoritarian outsider (Kevin Dillon) leads the charge, joined by cheerleader Meg (Shawnee Smith). When local authorities struggle in vain to contain the threat, mysterious government agents arrive to take the situation in hand, trying to cover up the evidence under suspicious circumstances. The overfamiliar machinations of the narrative are compensated for by state-of-the-art special effects (revelling in true gore here, the visuals leave little to the imagination) and the numerous scary moments that ensue. Cast includes Donovan Leitch, Jeffrey DeMunn, Candy Clark and Joe Seneca.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chuck Russell, Elliott Kastner, Jack H. Harris and Tri-Star Pictures

results.title: The Blob
results.brief_description: A drive-in favorite, this sci-fi classic follows teenagers Steve and his best girl, Jane, as they try to protect their hometown from a gelatinous alien life form that engulfs everything it touches. The first to discover the substance and live to tell about it, Steve and Jane witness the blob destroying an elderly man and grow to a terrifying size. But no one else has seen the goo, and policeman Dave refuses to believe the kids without proof.

results.title: The Blob
results.creator_credit: Irvin S. Yeaworth, Jack H. Harris and Valley Forge Films Studios
results.brief_description: The uncut colour version of the cult Sci-Fi film that established McQueen’s star quality. A small town becomes engulfed in terror when a meteorite crashes in a lonely field. McQueen and his girlfriend must convince the townsfolk to action but face total disbelief and ridicule towards what seems a fabrication by confused kids. A slimy alien gel begins swallowing people and growing larger. Classic scenes include a packed cinema screening a horror movie when the slimy gel seeps from the projector window causing an unforgetable exit of panic. Starring Steve McQueen, Aneta Corseaut and Earl Rowe. Co-starring Olin Howlin, Steven Chase and John Benson. Includes rare career highlights of Steve McQueen including famous film and television roles such as “Wanted: Dead or Alive”, “The Great Escape” and “The Defender” (with an early William “Star Trek” Shatner) and a very brief interview in relation to his off-screen dare-devil motor bike racing.

results.title: The Blizzard of Aahhh's
results.brief_description: Take three of the world’s best stunt skiers - cliff-jumper Scot Schmidt, extreme skier - Bad boy Glen Plake, and precision skier Mike Hattrup … transport them to the finest steep terrain in the world - from Switzerland to France’s Chamonix Valley to California’s awe inspiring Squaw Valley … engage some slick cameramen … set the results to an original soundtrack ranging from hot rap to Euro-funk, including Frankie Goes to Hollywood, Propaganda and ACT … and what do you have? “The Blizzard of AAHHH’s” - a vividly photographed, tightly edited rock video movie. Ever bolder jumps, twists, straight shots through chutes, games of chicken with crevasses and other activities designed to make insurance company rate-setters squeal with delight! Rated: G

results.title: The Blink of an eye
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
This is part two of “Filmstruck”, a series hosted by the well-known Australian film historian and cinema critic, John Baxter, which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience. In this episode, John Baxter takes a closer look at cinema stunts and the men that performed them, from early Tom Mix to Mad Max 2.

results.title: The Blinds and the Shutters
results.brief_description: This works presents a virtual world comprised of a modernist fictional house in a remote forest setting, whose contents gradually spill and float out of every aperture. Shoes and dresses, pots and pans, cutlery, pillows, blankets and plates journey in two directions simultaneously, some disappearing into the distance never to return, others appearing across all four screens in the installation. The larger objects fade up like apparitions, disappear and then reappear in strange locations, breaking all logic that is guiding this imaginary world. The slow drift of these household objects around the four screens is uncanny. While their journey suggests that the natural phenomenon of air is present, there is also a sense of airlessness; a claustrophobic, almost heavily scented environment. Despite sharing an energy force within the virtual environment, these objects are estranged – for they have lost their domestic relationship with one another. The sounds of bumps, collisions and muffled shuffles emerging from the interior of the house underscores the mystery of this scene. The disturbing atmosphere is most bizarre when the household goods are propelled into outer space, taking on the form of miniature satellites presumably tracking our behaviour from afar.

results.title: The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides
results.brief_description: The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them before staging performances like The Blind Man of Siloam.

constellations_primary.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_primary.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

results.description: The Salvation Army isn’t just a part of Melbourne’s social fabric – it’s also an integral part of moving-image history. The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in elaborate sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them in the department’s Bourke Street studio. The Blind Man of Siloam shows how this technique re-created ancient locations from hand-painted backgrounds. The department’s most famous show, Soldiers of the Cross, featured over 200 slides projected from multiple lanterns, as well as hymns, music, motion-picture segments and rousing narration.
description_for_label: The Salvation Army isn’t just a part of Melbourne’s social fabric – it’s also an integral part of moving-image history. The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in elaborate sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them in the department’s Bourke Street studio. The Blind Man of Siloam shows how this technique re-created ancient locations from hand-painted backgrounds. The department’s most famous show, Soldiers of the Cross, featured over 200 slides projected from multiple lanterns, as well as hymns, music, motion-picture segments and rousing narration.
